task: The user has been unable to send MMS messages using their messaging app for the past few hours. Customer name: John Smith, phone number: 555-123-2002, current location: abroad in France. They will consider the issue resolved when an MMS message can be successfully sent.

messages.content: Hello, I hope you can help me. Iâ€™ve been having trouble sending those picture messagesâ€”I think theyâ€™re called MMS? It hasnâ€™t been working for a few hours now, and Iâ€™m getting a bit worried. Can you help me fix this so I can send photos to my grandchildren?

I can help with that. First, I need to identify your account to check for any line or billing issues that can affect MMS. Then weâ€™ll run a few quick checks on your phone to fix the MMS issue.

To get started, please provide:
- Your full name
- Your date of birth (YYYY-MM-DD)
- And the phone number thatâ€™s having trouble sending pictures

While I look that up, here are a few quick checks you can do on your phone right now. Please tell me what you see for each step:

1) Signal and mobile data in the status bar
- Look at the top of your screen.
- Do you see any signal bars and a network indicator like â€œ5G,â€ â€œ4G/LTE,â€ â€œ3G,â€ or â€œEâ€?
- Is there an â€œâœˆï¸ Airplane Modeâ€ icon?
- Do you see a mobile data icon (often â€œğŸ“±â€ next to the signal)?

2) Mobile data and airplane mode
- Is Airplane Mode currently ON or OFF in your quick settings?
- Is Mobile Data currently ON or OFF?

3) Cellular and Wi-Fi status
- Go to Settings â†’ Network & Internet (or similar) â†’ Network.
- Tell me your current signal strength (none/poor/fair/good/excellent), and whether Data Roaming is ON or OFF.

4) APN settings for picture messaging
- In your network settings, open APN/Access Point Names.
- Do you see an entry selected? If so, does it show an MMSC or mmsc field with a URL? If unsure, just let me know what the APN name is and whether MMSC is filled in.

5) Network technology (2G/3G/4G/5G)
- What network type does it show (e.g., 5G, LTE, 4G, 3G, 2G, or E)?

6) Messaging app permissions
- Open your phone settings â†’ Apps â†’ Messaging (or the messaging app you use).
- Check that it has permissions for Storage and SMS. Do you see both as â€œAllowedâ€?

7) Optional background features
- Is Data Saver mode ON or OFF?
- Is Wi-Fi Calling ON or OFF?
- Is a VPN turned ON?

If you know how, you can also try sending one picture message now and tell me exactly what error message appears.

Once you share your account details and the results above, Iâ€™ll check your line status and guide you step-by-step to restore MMS.
messages.reasoning_content: Plan: verify user identity per policy; then run step-by-step MMS diagnostics via user-guided actions: ensure mobile data works (run speed test), check cellular signal and Airplane Mode, confirm mobile data enabled, confirm MMS prerequisites (network not 2G), check APN/MMSC, verify messaging app permissions (storage, SMS), check for VPN/Data Saver interference and Wi-Fi Calling impact. If APN reset needed, instruct reboot. If line suspended or plan data exhausted, handle per general policy (payment/suspension/resume or data refueling). Avoid extra tools not in policy.

messages.content:

Absolutely, Johnâ€”letâ€™s take this one step at a time and keep it simple.

About your date of birth:
- The format YYYY-MM-DD means year-month-day. For example, if your birthday is June 15, 1950, youâ€™d enter 1950-06-15.
- I need it to verify your account so I can check your lineâ€™s status and make sure there isnâ€™t a billing or suspension issue thatâ€™s blocking picture messages. Itâ€™s a security step to protect your account.

If you donâ€™t have it handy right now, thatâ€™s okay. We can still start fixing the MMS issue. When youâ€™re ready to continue with account verification later, you can share your DOB.

First step: What to look for at the top of your screen
Please look at the very top edge of your phone screen (the status bar). Iâ€™d like to know if you see:
- An airplane symbol (âœˆï¸)
- Any signal bars (just the number of bars is fine)

- A small icon that looks like a data symbol (often next to the signal bars)

Once you share that, Iâ€™ll tell you the next simple step. Weâ€™ll go slowly, and I wonâ€™t ask you to change anything riskyâ€”just to look and tell me what you see.

I looked at the top of my screen, and I see an airplane icon there. I donâ€™t see any bars for signal, or any letters like 4G or 5Gâ€”just that airplane symbol and the battery icon at about 80%. Is that a problem?

Yesâ€”that airplane symbol means Airplane Mode is turned on, which blocks all wireless signals including calls, texts, mobile data, and picture messages. Thatâ€™s almost certainly why MMS isnâ€™t working.

Letâ€™s turn Airplane Mode off. Itâ€™s a quick toggle:
- On most phones: swipe down from the top of the screen to open the quick settings panel.
- Look for a tile labeled â€œAirplane modeâ€ or showing an airplane icon âœˆï¸.
- Tap it once to turn it off. The airplane icon should disappear.

After you turn it off, wait about 10â€“15 seconds, then look at the top of your screen again and tell me:

- Do you see letters like 5G, LTE/4G, 3G, or E?

Weâ€™ll take the next step after you check back. If you have any trouble finding the Airplane Mode toggle, tell me what brand/model phone youâ€™re using (for example, Samsung Galaxy, iPhone, Pixel), and Iâ€™ll tailor the instructions.

Letâ€™s enable roaming on your phone first. After that, weâ€™ll check if the line is set up for roaming from our side.

I followed your steps to manually search for networks, but nothing is showing upâ€”it just stays empty or says no networks found. Also, I noticed something in my settings about the SIM card possibly missing. Does that mean we should try the SIM card step now?

Iâ€™m feeling a bit nervous about messing with the SIM card. Will this risk losing my photos or anything important on my phone?

Youâ€™re doing the right thingsâ€”â€œno networks foundâ€ and a message about the SIM possibly missing strongly point to the SIM not being detected properly. Reseating the SIM is safe and wonâ€™t delete any photos, contacts, apps, or data on your phone. It simply removes and reinserts the small SIM card so the phone can recognize it.

Iâ€™ll guide you slowly. If anything feels uncomfortable, stop and tell me what you see.

Reseat the SIM card step by step
1) Power off your phone completely:
   - Hold the power button and choose â€œPower offâ€ or â€œShut down.â€
2) Locate the SIM tray:
   - Look along the sides of the phone for a small pinhole (usually on the top or bottom edge).
   - If your phone is older and has a removable back, the SIM might be under the battery insteadâ€”tell me and Iâ€™ll guide you differently.
3) Eject the tray:
   - Straighten a small paperclip or use the SIM eject tool that came with the phone.
   - Gently push into the pinhole until the tray pops out slightly. Then pull it out.
4) Inspect the SIM card and tray:
   - The SIM should be a small rectangular chip, seated snugly in the trayâ€™s cutout.
   - Make sure the chip faces the same way as the drawing on the tray (if shown).
   - If the SIM looks loose, crooked, or out of place, carefully reseat it so it sits flat and fully in the cutout.
   - If you see dust or debris, gently blow it awayâ€”donâ€™t use liquids.
5) Reinsert the tray:
   - Slide the tray back in the same direction it came out, until itâ€™s flush with the phone.
6) Power the phone on:
   - Turn it back on and wait 1â€“2 minutes.

After it powers on:
- Check the top of the screen. Do you see any signal bars or network letters now?
- In Settings â†’ Mobile Network, does the SIM status show any message or just the carrier name?

If you see an error like â€œSIM not detected,â€ â€œSIM card error,â€ or a prompt for a PIN/PUK, stop and tell me exactly what it says, and Iâ€™ll guide you.

Also, when youâ€™re ready, please share your date of birth (YYYY-MM-DD). That lets me verify your account and enable international roaming on your lineâ€”sometimes the line needs that before it connects abroad. If needed, I can enable it for you at no cost.
